Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2010 09:37AM CandyB wrote: rayofsun, my daughter (16) is my verbal one. Teens just seem to go silent on us.  I've talked to others who've gone thru this w/teens & they've had similar experiences, kids don't talk about it much.  I know what you mean about the feeling alone.  I have supportive family & friends, but still feel very alone at times.  Everyone's supportive, but they have their own lives & issues.  I'm separated, so no significant other walking along with me on this one.  Maybe things like this discussion group can help us be alone together?  Glad you're being proaactive with the therapy!
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2010 01:35PM CandyB wrote: I found the packing list/what to do before & after surgery topic helpful on what to take to the hospital and have on hand afterwards.  My insurance covers one of the camisoles that velcros up the front & has 4 pockets inside for the drains, so I got one last week while at a PS appt.  On being disorganized -- a gross understatement for me!  My brain feels like a pinball bouncing from thing to thing.  I'm working through the 31st, then surgery on the 5th, & off the month of April.  So trying to organize my job for others to make heads or tails, organize my house for my sisters to make heads or tails of, etc.  I've got lists of things to do, but keep losing them! Feeling scared, ready to get it over with, numb, and much more on top of it all.  Comforting to know there's support here of women who understand.
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2010 08:47AM CandyB wrote: OK ladies -- I wanted to let you know I had my BMX w/ SNB & TE on Monday & I'm doing fine.  I hope those of you still to go will find this encouraging.  I came home Tuesday morning.  Prelim path report is clear nodes!  Expecting the final path report today or tomorrow.  I have 4 drains in which are doing fine.  My new best friend is a pain pump that has 2 small catheters, one to each side of my chest, which constantly drips a local numbing med in.  This has eliminated the need, so far, for the heavy duty pain meds.  I have Percoset on hand, but have only used Tylenol extra strength so far.  That's made me pretty clear headed.  If it's available where you are, I highly recommned the pump.  Been sleeping okay.  Resting a lot, but surgeon wants me up walking & doing deep breathing every hour I'm awake.  I'm sure I'll do plenty of grieving for my breasts, but for now I just feel relief that's it's over with and the cancer is out of my body.  Relief is really the overwhelming emotion I feel at this point. Everyone's experience will be different, but I hope each of your experiences goes as smoothly as mine.  Just wanted to offer some encouragement to you all.  Oh, & I just took a shower -- felt so good!  Thinking of you all as your dates come along.
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: May 5, 2010 12:59PM CandyB wrote: Hey, ladies.  I've been reading, but not writing for a while.  I'm one month out today!  I started back to work on Monday.  Thanks to an understanding, flexible boss, I'm able to phase in as I feel up to it.  Only wish the utilities, grocery store, credit card company, etc. were as flexible.  Anyway, I've been very fortunate with nominal pain and swelling, but am still feeling much fatigue.  Anyone else?  I'm sure it's the energy drain from my body healing, the emotional issues (do they ever stop?), and frustration over my limited activity.  But still -- it reminds me of the first trimester of pregnancy exhaustion.  I could hardly keep my eyes open during my daughter's choir concert last night.  Did I mention crankiness?  Really cranky, too.  Hopefully, that's from the exhaustion and emotions.  Just wondering if anyone else from the April group is experiencing tiredness and emotional roller coaster?  Also, met with my oncologist yesterday -- very frustrating lack of choices.  I'm taking that up in the hormonal therapy group. Hope that a new month is finding everyone recovering!  We'll all blossom with the spring.
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2010 06:09AM CandyB wrote: Hello fellow April ladies.  Question for you.  I chose to go through reconstruction and am having my nipple reconstruction tomorrow.  This will be a relatively minor surgery, recovery over the week-end and should be back to "normal"  (whatever that is these days!) next week.  So my question is -- anyone else having a hard time mentally with doing any follow up surgery?  This will be on the scale of wisdom teeth removal or a colonoscopy (without the yucky drinks), yet I'm dreading it WAY out of proportion.  I don't freak out over general anesthesia, just really dreading ANY surgery.  I'm thinking it's just the association I now have with the idea of surgery, because the bi mast. was so major.  I'm really dreading tomorrow, but want to complete my reconstruction.  Am I crazy?
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2010 09:09AM CandyB wrote: Victoria & brigidko, make sure you get a 2nd & even 3rd opinion.  Do  you have a nurse or other person that's working with you through the process?  I'm in Indianapolis & have a nurse navigator who's been wonderful in helping me think through my decision making, without telling me what to do.  You can also check with local cancer organizations for someone to discuss it with.  Forgive me if these are "well, duh" ideas.  I've appreciated people helping me think of resources, even if I already thought of them.  I have a sister who had a masectomy 19 years ago, my BF had a lumpectomy 3 years ago, and a good friend who had a bmx w/reconstruction this past fall.  They've been helpful in sharing their thoughts on making the choices and regrets/non-regrets.  I'll be happy to share those with you, if you're interested.  Bottom line is it just sucks because there aren't any "good" choices.
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2010 07:23AM CandyB wrote: Paxton - so happy for you! Beck - it's not barging in.  The encouragement is much needed & appreciated! algreach - I'm a single parent, too.  Know what you mean about worrying about the impact.  It's hard for all parents, but especially if you're the primary (only?) parent in the picture.  How old is your daughter?  My kids are 13, 16 & 20, so old enough that they've gone into quiet mode.  They don't want to talk much about what's going on.  Friends who've been through bc say their kids were much the same.  I'm trying not to worry, but can't help but be concerned about what's going on below the surface.  Today's my last day of work, I'll be out of the office all of April.  A very strange feeling to be wrapping everything up & thinking about what Monday holds.  Trying not to panic.  Am ready to get this over with, find out exactly what the SNB shows, know what I'm dealing with, deal with it, recover, & move on.  I want my life back!
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2010 10:31AM CandyB wrote: For those of you facing surgery this coming week -- it feels so good to get to the other side.  My recovery (surgery was 4/5) is still going well.  My pain pump ran out Thursday night & I've taken a Tylenol III each night but still only 4 to 6 extra strength Tylenol during the day when I feel the need.  Movement is coming back, though still quite limited.  Sleeping propped up in bed has worked okay.  Rolling out of bed is still the most painful thing.  Sump pump stuck Wednesday night flooding the basement.  Not what I needed.  After the initial desire to lose it, I realized it was way down the priority ladder.  Friends & neighbors helped fix and clean up while I stood around feeling helpless.  Same with my son's glasses getting run over & destroyed last night.  My cancer's gone, I can handlel sump pumps and glasses. I had a panic moment when I got on the operation table, but have felt peace since then.  Waiting was the hardest, hands down, no question about it. Got my final path report, the 4 nodes were clear & no signs of anything on the right side.  Cancer was 1.4 cm., so no unexpected findings.   They're running an oncotype DX which will take about 2 weeks to get back.  It'll have to be a fairly high score to convince me to do chemo, but I'm trying to stay open minded. Hang in there, ladies.  Having it over is huge!  I, too, have not been shocked by the sight of my chest.  I'd looked at lots of photos to brace myself & I'm comfortable with what I have.  The TEs are far from attractive, but the incisions aren't too bad.  I'm thinking that I may agree with one woman on one of the topics that said she's much more embarrassed by the cellulite are her thighs than her scars.  Strength & courage is a good mantra to chant this week-end!.
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: May 30, 2010 08:39PM CandyB wrote: hope4future -- had to respond to your question about being tired.  I'm 8 weeks out, as of tomorrow.  It took me at least 6 weeks to stop napping on the days that I could fit it in.  I kept feeling like a wimp becasue I've always been hale and hearty, never been a napper.  My mother would tell you that I wasn't a napper even as a small child, much to her sorrow.  I went back to work after 4 weeks, but I have a desk job.  I'm very fortunate in that I'm not having chemo or radiation, just started tamoxifen a few days ago.  I had no reason to be tired!  But I was.  Friends and family have convinced me that it's just a long healing process -- physically and emotionally.  We have to listen to our bodies.  If you're feeling tired, rest when you can.  The long-term healing is most important.  We've all got lots of balls in the air that we're juggling and a list of things to do that never, ever ends.  But take it easy as much as possible.  There doesn't seem to be a formula for when the tiredness ends.  I can tell you that in the last week I've been feeling much more myself.  I have much more energy, my mind is clearer (not clear, but better!), and I feel happy.  It'll come  for you!
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2010 11:48AM CandyB wrote: Thank you for this group, count me in.  April 5th bmx w/TE for me.  Was scheduled for the 6th, which hit me driving to work yesterday that I was 3 weeks away.  It hit me hard.  To top it off, my PS's office called yesterday to say that it had to be rescheduled to the 5th, not the 6th.  So, had to switch to 3 weeks away I'll be home & on the way to recovery.  brigidko, these dates are soon!  Hope you have someone to talk to about the double vs. single.  I'm only Stage I, but opted for double because of epidemic family history & breasts that are very difficult to detect.  Mine only showed up on MRI, not mammo or ultrasound.  Who knows what it would have been if waited for mammo?  I'm a bit freaked by the idea of having my breasts removed, losing sensation, etc., but am confident that it's the way for me to go.  I'm on a "cadillac" insurance plan now, but will be losing that after pending divorce, so had to consider future insurance bull along with all the other considerations.  I keep hearing that it'a a very individual decision.  I agree, but that's a huge understatement!  If you need to bounce ideas off, this seems like a great place.  Anyone out there with kids?  I have 3 - 13, 16 & 20.  They're being very stoic, I think they're in "don't cause Mom any grief" mode, which is nice on the one hand.  But -- I want them to know that it's OK to be worried, etc.  Any thoughts on dealing w/kids this way?  I had a low day yesterday & just ended up telling the 2 younger ones at dinner that my day sucked.  Of course, that was after hiding in the bathroom to cry for a bit.  Hoping that letting them know I'm struggling at times will help them feel it's OK to show when it's not so good.  BTW - the cry in the bathroom was therapeutic & followed up w/a dose of watching beautiful sunset & listening to birds while enjoying a glass of wine on the back porch.  Good advice I got from my BF: no one will thank you for NOT taking care of yourself.  I'm feeling massively overwhelmed trying to get everything organized at work & home before the surgery, in addition to the psychology of it all.  I'm sure anyone in this group is feeling much the same.  Please let's remind each other to slow down & take care of ourselves.  The stronger we go into this, the better we'll come out!
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 06:17AM CandyB wrote: Any one still checking in?  I haven't been, but coming up on the 1 year anniversary, it's been on my mind, so thought I'd stop by.  What a year, eh?  My 14-year old son is having hernia surgery on the anniversary of my BMX, which is just kind of odd for me.  His is just 1 hour outpatient and at a different hospital than where I had my surgery.  Most of all I hate the idea of my baby being put under, even for a short time, but around the fringes of that are bad memories of my own experience.  Will be glad when it's done! I hope everyone is ending this year doing much better and the next year brings happiness!
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 01:35PM CandyB wrote: Jessamine: I know what you mean.  My "foobs" aren't great.  They look great in clothes, which I guess is something, but they're funny looking naked.  I know I'll never have real boobs again, so don't know how much we're supposed to accept as the new reality (I don't like that phrase!) or is it worth to go through more surgery?  I don't have an answer for you.  Yet another one of those decisions we each have to make, but it does suck to be unhappy with the results.  I know there are many who say we deserve the best possible, but it's not worth more surgery for me.  The intrusion, disruption, and recovery are difficult.  I'm a single parent, so it's hard to juggle being down and out.  And for what?  Like you say -- will I get better results?  Infection?  Just don't know.
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine
